item.title: Write a thousand songs
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
I listened to an interview with Imagine Dragons. The lead singer talked about how he writes several songs per day.

No wonder he‚Äôs so successful. Repetitions breeds opportunity.

This has two affects on the brain. 1) lowers the pressure of individual songs. Don‚Äôt need to knock it of the park. 2) you get better at writing that much faster.

I heard once about a photography that let one half of the students only take 5 photos in a semester. The other half had to take 100. Which group had the better photos?

You miss 100% of the shots you don‚Äôt take. Wayne Gretzky Michael Scott

item.title: When Leaders Lose their People
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
In a scene in Dune, Paul notices that his warrior turns into his worshipper. He laments the loss, wondering if his non-religious warrior will be lost too.

Being a worshipped means you‚Äôre worshipped. Unchallenged. Can do no wrong. As such, you‚Äôre left with the intellect of one.

As a leader, you need to avoid worshippers. People who fail to challenge you out of fear or an abundance of praise. This all has to do in the decisions you make as a leader. The culture you decide to build. Is every voice heard, or does one voice rule them all?

item.title: The Multiverse of Careers
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
Spoken about in The Dream State of Software, Paul of Dune has a moment where he‚Äôs both past and present in his mind. He doesn‚Äôt know even whether he‚Äôs had his kid or not.

In a podcast I listened to lately on happiness, one suggestion was to write out all your goals and cross them off from day one. Pretend like it doesn‚Äôt even matter if you accomplish them. This helps free you.

Careers are like both of these things. We want everything. We can pretend like we have it. We can come to terms with it. And we can say ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt matter if I don‚Äôt get that, because I‚Äôve got a life outside my career.‚Äù

Consider your career from your deathbed (My Tombstone). What path did you take that mattered? What were all the alternate realities and multiverses you could have had.

Put them all together. In one multiverse you‚Äôve been fired. In another you end up getting insanely wealthy. In another you start your own company. In another you become an online blogger.

All of them can‚Äôt be true when you do this exercise extensively enough. And choosing which one probably doesn‚Äôt matter as much (right vs wrong path thinking). If you‚Äôve ever left a job you realize that nothing really comes over with you. Most relationships at work are short lived and contextual, like your relationships in high school. And that‚Äôs life.

Happiness is perhaps being okay with not having everything you desire, except for the few things that are truly attainable: peace with God, self, and cherished relationships.

item.title: When a Person Changes their Perspective on Christ
item.description:
The Book of Mormon had 12 witnesses of its divinity - the three spiritual testimonies by the Three Witnesses, the Eight Witnesses with a physical witness, and Joseph Smith, the one who translated it as prophet, seer, and revelator. Powerfully, all Three Witnesses left the church years later (1937/38) nearly 8-9 years after writing their testimony (1829), but never left their testimonies:

Despite differences with Joseph Smith that led each of the Three Witnesses to part ways individually with the Church (Cowdery and Harris later returned), they continued to affirm their testimony as witnesses throughout their lives. Witnesses of the Book of Mormon

When a loved one leaves their testimony

Let‚Äôs consider the world where these three denied their testimonies. (It‚Äôs easy to see that they ‚Äúnever doubted their own witness, therefore it must be true‚Äù.) But I think this is a sandy foundation because a thing should be true regardless of what three individuals say about it.

Those who believe in Christ hold strong beliefs in Him, and it must be a belief because they cannot see Him. They rely on the faith built on personal witness and also built by the testimony of others. But what do you do when a loved one abandons their testimony, or becomes an unbeliever? Do you doubt everything you learned from them? Perhaps.

Who do you trust - the ‚Äúthem‚Äù now that un-believes, or the ‚Äúthem‚Äù then that once believed?

Consider a hard-and-fast alternative: what if someone began doubting the existence of gravity? What if they were once your physics professor? Easy: you just go to the apple tree and demonstrate the principle by dropping an apple. ‚ÄúNo, that‚Äôs magnetism‚Äù, the professor now claims.

You‚Äôre kind of stuck: well, if you think it‚Äôs magnetism, there‚Äôs not much I can do - this concept is called gravity. Similarly, people leave God‚Äôs path and believe the Hand of God that acts in their live is now, and always has been, just coincidence, luck, etc. what else could it be?

But what is coincidence? Luck? (I ponder these things often as a statistician. For another time‚Ä¶)

Putting a name on a Concept

There‚Äôs precedence for this - when Ammon appeared to the Lamanites, they thought he acted by the Great Spirit. Instead of telling them they were wrong, he instead clarified, ‚Äúthat great spirit is God‚Äù.

26 And then Ammon said: Believest thou that there is a Great Spirit? 27 And he said, Yea. 28 And Ammon said: This is God. And Ammon said unto him again: Believest thou that this Great Spirit, who is God, created all things which are in heaven and in the earth?
Alma 18.26‚Äì28

Likewise, when unbelievers doubt the Hand of God, or re-cast their old ways according to a new belief framework, perhaps they‚Äôre just labeling a concept in a different way. (It‚Äôs also really hard to know what someone once considered ‚ÄúGod‚Äù vs not in their life, so take this point with a grain of salt.)

After all, when people leave God some claim they were under confirmation bias, the concept that you favor the evidence that supports your belief. Hyndman argues confirmation bias can go both ways, for believers and unbelievers, but does claim that evidence favors the skeptics because there should be evidence. I‚Äôd argue he relies solely on physical evidence. There is spiritual evidence to be considered. Spiritual evidence is what we believe in. It‚Äôs what the Three Witnesses relied on. It‚Äôs unprovable to anyone else, and only receivable by the Holy Ghost. If God exists, let Him reveal himself. Let Him prevail:

But whom say ye that I am? 16 And Simon Peter answered and said, Thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God. 17 And Jesus answered and said unto him, Blessed art thou, Simon Bar-jona: for flesh and blood hath not revealed it unto thee, but my Father which is in heaven.
Matthew 16.15‚Äì17

The most powerful thing about being a Christian is that it cannot be proven Christ didn‚Äôt exist or walk the earth. Even if you falsify the entire bible, erase history, or discover that ‚ÄúMary‚Äù was an invented concept by some creed or counsel bound to oppress us - there‚Äôs still a question: did the Man exist? We can debate it. Pharisees debated if He was That Messiah. Nobody now can know, except God reveals it to them.

Why? Because to claim God doesn‚Äôt exist, or the plates weren‚Äôt real, you‚Äôd also have to have evidence. Counter-evidence isn‚Äôt evidence. Lack of evidence likewise. Don‚Äôt we continually find new fossils? New animals in the wild? Lack of evidence doesn‚Äôt mean they don‚Äôt exist.1

  • 1 The other side may say (as Hyndman) does), I might as well believe in the Tooth Fairy, or Santa, because I don‚Äôt have evidence they don‚Äôt exist. Fair. Then belief is a choice, and must follow the principle of ‚Äúby their fruits ye shall know them‚Äù. Did Baal call down Fire? No, only Elijah‚Äôs God. ‚ÄúWas that story of the Bible invented?‚Äù Perhaps. If so, explain why living Christ‚Äôs gospel brings me joy? ‚ÄúBecause they‚Äôre good principles‚Äù, well, what is good, if not God? ‚ÄúWell then why not Zeus, or Baal to be your God?‚Äù, because I believe in the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob - not the God of Baal. I believe the scriptures because they teach good things. ‚ÄúWhat about the misogyny, racism, war and killing in the Bible etc etc etc‚Äù, well, perhaps some was commanded by God for reasons and context we don‚Äôt have. Perhaps some of the Bible isn‚Äôt truely written. ‚ÄúIf some isn‚Äôt true it‚Äôs all not true because parts of it say it‚Äôs all true‚Äù. Well, what‚Äôs true is true, what‚Äôs not isn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs to say what God inspired?‚Äù Well, who‚Äôs to say what‚Äôs not inspired? Only God. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not getting anywhere‚Äù. Ahh, but we are. Because I believe in God, and after believing Him I exercised faith in His son to pray on His name and open myself to trying to follow His ways. I‚Äôm far from perfect, but once I did this, I received spiritual knowledge, and having seen more of the Hand of God in my life, I can say there are miracles of events I can‚Äôt explain by chance or delusion alone. Miracles only a loving God could produce. This is my knowledge, which follows faith. Alma 32.34‚Äì36 And we also have the Book of Mormon, which is a powerful second witness of Christ that brought reality to the truth in the Bible, and continually helps me feel the fruits of the Spirit, which is the Holy Ghost telling me it‚Äôs true.

  • 2 my whole life until 21 I had no idea Joseph Smith had so many (up to 42) wives. ‚ÄúSome say he was a womanizer, pimp, etc‚Äù. Perhaps. But perhaps he was a prophet commanded to do so. Were we there? God at one point commanded Abraham to raise seed and have many wives. ‚ÄúMaybe Abraham was a philanderer too.‚Äù Okay, but does that definition of chastity and virtue not depend on the very construction of marriage as ordained by God who married Adam and Eve as husband and wife? If it‚Äôs from God, it‚Äôs His law, and He chose the rules. ‚ÄúBut Joseph altered the rules and made stuff up so he could get with women and teenagers.‚Äù Perhaps. That assumes we know him, he told us that, and he believed it to be true. So we‚Äôll leave it as an opinion. In my opinion he followed a commandment from an Angel, despite me not understanding it entirely or being comfortable with the idea. Let the man speak for himself.

    • To prove the Abrahamic God doesn‚Äôt exist people just say ‚Äúwell I found all this stuff about the bible, about church leaders, etc‚Äù was wrong or misconstrued. So? First, we have to make sure the ‚Äúnew stuff‚Äù learned is actually true (could be a lie), but if it is true (that something you once believed is a lie or misunderstanding) we must find out how this fits into Christ‚Äôs bigger picture.2

    You can‚Äôt claim that Joseph Smith didn‚Äôt see God and that the Three Witnesses didn‚Äôt see the plates at some point. Because you weren‚Äôt there in 1829. Even if they had later denied, from reading Killers of the Flower Moon: the Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI, it‚Äôs quite clear how people can be manipulated in the courts of law, influenced by money, influenced by their own delusions, etc. Since delusions go both ways, relying on people at all isn‚Äôt how we learn the existence of a Divine. Peter learned of Christ‚Äôs divinity the way we all must (quote above). Show me the evidence, says the scientist in me: the spiritual evidence. # Flip Floppers on Both Sides

    Floppers flip both ways. The quote above said another way: who‚Äôs witness do you trust - the you of today, the you of yesterday, or the you of tomorrow? We can all come and go with our testimonies. This is life. We must have an unalterable way to learn truth, one independent of our path.

    We‚Äôve got the Paul‚Äôs of the world who were once Christian persecutors who flip to believers, and we‚Äôve got those who claimed Joseph Smith was a fallen prophet after being in vision with him.

    We‚Äôre all more like Laman and Lemuel than we realize. We see things that make us believe, we come to God, and then we forget and wonder if they never happened.

    We‚Äôre all flip floppers. Let us not seek truth alone from others, or even rely solely on the Prophet. Our testimonies must be on Christ, and learning truth by the Holy Ghost, who will then guide us to understand the words of prophets and imperfect leaders. It‚Äôs good science.

    In coming days, it will not be possible to survive spiritually without the guiding, directing, comforting, and constant influence of the Holy Ghost.
    ‚ÄúRevelation for the Church, Revelation for Our Lives‚Äù, Russell M. Nelson

    I‚Äôm glad the Three Witnesses never denied their testimonies, but I‚Äôm glad there‚Äôs a way to know the Book of Mormon is true without them. After all, those dudes didn‚Äôt answer my prayer about the book‚Äôs truth. Heavenly Father did.

    _________________________

item.title: Your Mood is Contagious
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
There‚Äôs no question that moods are contagious. I once asked someone at the beach to leash their dog, and they slightly rebuked me, ‚Äúthis is a dog friendly beach.‚Äù Well, so it is, I thought, grumpily. I complained to a family member about this grumpy dog owner.

Moods escalate. And negative moods are even more pervasive and contagious than positive ones. They say a disgruntled customer tells more friends and family than happy ones. Why is this?

In the ‚ÄúBlack Cat‚Äù (The Best of Edgar Allen Poe), Poe describes a gruesome tale man who wanted to do evil just for the sake of it. That it‚Äôs in his nature. Not because you want to do the thing, but because you want to do a forbidden thing. The same goes the other way, for sure. But I think we trend slightly pessimistic because being an optimist is more beneficial, more rewarding and therefore more difficult.

A leader once told me when I was managing a team, ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll pick up on everything you do or say.‚Äù Oddly, I was picking up on what he was saying.

So when you lead, lead carefully. Whether in home or work, lead with kindness, compassion, and restraint. Speak three kind words before a negative. Ask to understand before assuming. Lead as a servant. It takes all the effort to overcome negative vibes, and who better equipped than the leader to do it?

Don‚Äôt be Moriarty:

‚ÄúWhy can‚Äôt you be more hopeful for a change?‚Äù

item.title: Writing Ethos
item.description:
List of reasons why I write this blog and principles I aspire to. They evolve over time, and I like to keep track.

2023-12-31

  • Write every day (Seth Godin style). Many posts will be bad. But higher repetitions means better writing.
  • Learn by writing. Synthesis only happens when sharing.
  • Write first, edit later.
  • Use writing to actively digest world news. Doomscrolling is futile and anxiety inducing. Writing and synthesizing helps me comparmentalize the world and where I fit into it.
  • Develop an opinion. Strong opinions, weakly held. A ship is better heading in any direction than none at all. An opinion is a direction.
  • Every post is a story. If it‚Äôs not a story, it‚Äôs not worth reading.
  • I am me. I write what‚Äôs on my mind. I hope it‚Äôs interesting to different people in different ways.
  • Write each post for one real person in my life, based on one real discussion.
  • Gratitude is healing, produces optimism, and reveals a new way. Give thanks daily. I give thanks, therefore I have.

2022-12-05

  • All blogs are wrong, but some are useful (riff on George Box‚Äôs quote that all models are wrong)

item.title: The Dream State of Software
item.description:
I returned from vacation yesterday and tried running my code. It didn‚Äôt work. I looked at code I had written, it had my imports correctly and all - why wasn‚Äôt it running?

The file it was importing didn‚Äôt exist.

I thought I created that. I swear I made it. My coworker remarked, ‚Äúoh so you set up all the scafffolding but didn‚Äôt write the actual code?‚Äù I was in disbelief. maybe it was deleted by accident or stashed on another branch. But the git log shows all: the imported file never existed.

In Dune, Paul Atriedes has many visions and the author uses this feature to skip the book ahead three years. Paul wakes up one morning and doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs past or future. It‚Äôs all one in his mind.

So it is with software. It gets created in the mind near instantly. Coding is a burden, the journey of many failures and design choices to enable the simple vision of the mind.

Perhaps Gen AI can help us dream software faster. I look forward to when my dreams are realities, and not the rude awakening I still have coding to do.

And we give our names unto the world, to witness unto the world that which we have seen. And we lie not, God bearing witness of it. Testimony of Eight Witnesses

I admire any who live with such conviction. It calls to mind the John Hancock‚Äôs of the world.

We‚Äôre invited to ‚Äústand as witnesses of God at all times and in all things, and in all places that ye may be in,‚Äù (Mosiah 18.9), to share what we‚Äôve seen.

item.title: My Tombstone
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
They call it a death meditation, to look back from the end of your life and reflect as if you had just died (out of body style). Here‚Äôs my tombstone:

Here lies Bryan, son of Aragon, data scientist extraordinaire who knew how to use regular expressions and properly test linear regression assumptions

Seem like a good tombstone?

Why do we measure our lives by something nobody cares about? Consider Steve Jobs, Isaac Newton, or whomever you idolize. What are they known for? Only a few things.

I read Steve Jobs (Biography) a while back. And I also read Leonardo da Vinci. First was 25 hours, second was 17 hours. And guess what - that‚Äôs less than two days combined. Two ‚Äúimpressive‚Äù lives summed up in a few days.

My grandma‚Äôs obituary was brief. Yet her life was filled with millions of unwritten sentences - many written on my life. The in between moments. The laying around moments. The relationship moments. (Maybe it‚Äôs called a relation-‚Äúship‚Äù because it sails the waters of life continuously, despite the infrequent dock postings.)

Nobody‚Äôs going to remember me, except those who call me dad, husband, brother, son, and friend. And I‚Äôm okay with that. I was never that good at data science anyway üòâ.

item.title: Love Thy Neighbor, But Have Friends
item.description:
Christ invited us to love our neighbors:

thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself: I am the Lord. Leviticus 19.18

But He himself had his friends: his disciples. He didn‚Äôt try hanging out with the Pharisees or the Romans. He spent time at dinner with his apostles and followers.

He had four brothers. Did he call them to apostleship? No. Did he not love them? No, he loved them.

He loved the Roman as much as he loved John the Beloved: enough to die for them and prepare the way for them to rejoin him in heaven.

But he also spent time with those he loved. What does this teach us about love?

item.title: The miracles of Christ
item.description:
I‚Äôm reading the Book of Mormon this year with the Come Follow Me (by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints) curriculum. I hope you enjoy as I write something I learn each day.

I‚Äôll tag things ‚Äúscripture of the day‚Äù for any one-scripture thoughts. If it‚Äôs related to the Come Follow Me theme, l‚Äôll add a tag.

Miracles of Christ

This scripture caught me eye:

For behold, the time cometh, and is not far distant, that with power, the Lord Omnipotent who reigneth, who was, and is from all eternity to all eternity, shall come down from heaven among the children of men, and shall dwell in a tabernacle of clay, and shall go forth amongst men, working mighty miracles, such as healing the sick, raising the dead, causing the lame to walk, the blind to receive their sight, and the deaf to hear, and curing all manner of diseases. Mosiah 3.5

I have seen miracles in my life. I‚Äôve also seen collateral-miracles, which is the miracle that happens when you‚Äôre expecting one thing but another thing happens instead.

I‚Äôve seen someone healed from a Priesthood blessing. I‚Äôve seen someone healed from depression. I‚Äôve seen someone healed from doubt and disbelief. I‚Äôve felt the power of the Holy Ghost in my life.

I‚Äôve also seen people not healed, left to the struggles we all face, and yet miracles abound.

So what is a miracle? Is it an outcome? No. It‚Äôs the process of seeing how an event can be changed by God for the benefit of an individual. Occasionally, there are supernatural changes in the natural course of things.

If any of these things sounds fanciful to those not of my Church, it‚Äôs actually a lot more simple and plain than it sounds. Because ‚Äúthe Lord was not in the wind: and after the wind an earthquake; but the Lord was not in the earthquake: And after the earthquake a fire; but the Lord was not in the fire: and after the fire a still small voice.‚Äù (1 Kings 19.11‚Äì12) For me, seeing a miracle of Christ is perceiving the hand by how he operates.

Some have a hard time reading the Old Testament because how can a God who brought fire from heaven, parted the seas, gave manna from heaven also be a God who doesn‚Äôt do those things today?

I‚Äôd argue the miracles of Christ have risen to the point where he works according to our knowledge and insight. I believe in a Christ who is the source of all truth, and who teaches truth (even scientific) to everyone, regardless of their belief system. Matthew 5.45

And so, the miracles of God today are happening within science. Within tech. He doesn‚Äôt have to heal us by God‚Äôs power if he gave us medicine to do the same.

He also doesn‚Äôt show his miracles the same way. The people of the Old Testament were simple. They needed signs. But signs aren‚Äôt faith, and I believe these days before His second coming are days of greater faith. Days where we‚Äôll have fewer signs.

Therefore, blessed are they who humble themselves without being compelled to be humble; or rather, in other words, blessed is he that believeth in the word of God, and is baptized without stubbornness of heart, yea, without being brought to know the word, or even compelled to know, before they will believe. Yea, there are many who do say: If thou wilt show unto us a sign from heaven, then we shall know of a surety; then we shall believe. 18 Now I ask, is this faith? Behold, I say unto you, Nay; for if a man knoweth a thing he hath no cause to believe, for he knoweth it. Alma 32.16‚Äì18

item.title: The Psychology of New Software Releases and its Parallels with Fashion
item.description:
What is it about a new release that gets people excited? Would you buy software that never changes? How about a hammer?

Why are we okay with buying a hammer, but not stagnant software? Our culture is addicted to new widgets. A/B testing.

Software releases are free, but development is not. Therefore, research and development is constant, whereas the Hammer company hasn‚Äôt needed to update its product in a couple‚Ä¶millennia. That‚Äôs why they call it software. It‚Äôs not hard to make.

Is there a way to sell software like you sell a hammer?

No. Because per Innovator‚Äôs Dilemma, those who can out-do you will. And software is easy to alter and improve. I‚Äôm not convinced all ‚Äúupdates‚Äù done in the software industry are actually improvements, but people like change. Ever see a fashion line repeat itself?

Software is like fashion.

item.title: Good Books
item.description:
I‚Äôm grateful for good books. They take time. They take effort. They‚Äôre art (I‚Äôm grateful for artists).
